Authors: Anquetin J., Milner A.R.
Title: A cautionary tail: Cyrtura temnospondyla Jaekel, 1904, an enigmatic vertebrate specimen from the Late Jurassic Solnhofen Limestone
Affiliations: Section d'archéologie et paléontologie, Office de la culture, République et Canton du Jura, Hôtel des Halles, Porrentruy, Switzerland; UMR CNRS 7207 MNHN UPMC, Muséum national d'histoire naturelle, CP38, 8, rue Buffon, Paris cedex 05, France; Department of Earth Sciences, The Natural History Museum, Cromwell Road, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Anquetin, J., Section d'archéologie et paléontologie, Office de la culture, République et Canton du Jura, Hôtel des Halles, Porrentruy, Switzerland, UMR CNRS 7207 MNHN UPMC, Muséum national d'histoire naturelle, CP38, 8, rue Buffon, Paris cedex 05, France; Milner, A.R., Department of Earth Sciences, The Natural History Museum, Cromwell Road, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The enigmatic vertebrate taxon Cyrtura temnospondyla is reassessed following the location and reuniting of both counterparts. The specimen, comprising a series of caudal vertebrae from the Tithonian Solnhofen Limestone, has variously been interpreted as derived either from a temnospondyl amphibian, or a turtle, or to be indeterminate. The redescription of this caudal series reveals that the vertebrae have a single centrum, in contrast to previous descriptions. This specimen is here interpreted to be the tail of a turtle more derived than Proganochelys and Meiolania, but is otherwise indeterminate and cannot be associated with any of the diagnosed taxa from the Solnhofen Limestone. C. temnospondyla lacks any diagnostic character and must therefore be considered a nomen dubium. © 2014 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Caudal vertebrae; Late Jurassic; Solnhofen; Temnospondyl; Turtle
Index Keywords: amphibian; Jurassic; limestone; morphology; taxonomy; turtle; type specimen; Bavaria; Germany; Solnhofen; Amphibia; Testudines; Vertebrata

Authors: Carayon D., Vaysse F., Tramini P., Dumoncel J., Esclassan R.
Title: The age-related maturational pattern of the human subarcuate fossa (petromastoid canal). Preliminary results from the application of a new three-dimensional analytical approach
Affiliations: Laboratoire Anthropobiologie moléculaire et imagerie de synthèse (AMIS), UMR 5288 CNRS - Université de Toulouse Paul-Sabatier, 37, allée Jules-Guesde, Toulouse, France; UFR d'Odontologie Montpellier-I, 545, avenue du Professeur-Jean-Louis-Viala, Montpellier, France; UFR d'Odontologie Toulouse-III, Avenue des Maraîchers, Toulouse, France

Abstract: The subarcuate fossa, or petromastoid canal, is a hypostotic feature of the temporal bone used for assessing the age at death of immature individuals. The present study uses the high-resolution micro-CT record of 20 extant human infant and juvenile temporal bones to more precisely assess the age-related maturational pattern of this bony structure. In the perspective of the application of our analytical protocol to the study of the hominid fossil record, the main goals of this contribution are to extend the amount and to improve the quality of the linear and volumetric information on the human subarcuate fossa by the application of new 3D imaging techniques. © 2014 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: 3D image analysis; Bony labyrinth; Development; Human temporal bone; Micro-CT scanner; Subarcuate fossa
Index Keywords: age determination; analytical framework; bone; maturation; three-dimensional modeling; Hominidae

Authors: Pan Z., Zhu M., Zhu Y., Jia L.
Title: A new petalichthyid placoderm from the early devonian of Yunnan, China
Affiliations: Key Laboratory of Vertebrate Evolution and Human Origins of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PO Box 643, Beijing, China; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Pan, Z., Key Laboratory of Vertebrate Evolution and Human Origins of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PO Box 643, Beijing, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Zhu, M., Key Laboratory of Vertebrate Evolution and Human Origins of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PO Box 643, Beijing, China; Zhu, Y., Key Laboratory of Vertebrate Evolution and Human Origins of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PO Box 643, Beijing, China; Jia, L., Key Laboratory of Vertebrate Evolution and Human Origins of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PO Box 643, Beijing, China
Abstract: Pauropetalichthys magnoculus, a new genus and species within the Petalichthyida (Gnathostomata: Placodermi), is described from the Late Emsian (Early Devonian) of Qujing, Yunnan, southwestern China. A three-dimensional reconstruction of the skull roof and neurocranium based on high-resolution computed tomography reveals the pattern of sensory canals, the visceral surface of the skull roof, and the profile of the endocranium. The perichondral lining of the nasal capsules provides the first hard evidence of nasal capsules in petalichthyids. A phylogenetic analysis resolves the new taxon as the most basal member of the Quasipetalichthyidae, an endemic group sister to the Macropetalichthyidae. In light of the newly revealed endocranial features, we discuss the morphological disparity of petalichthyid endocrania. The paleogeographic distribution of the Petalichthyida is summarized to show the group's center of origin and routes of dispersal. © 2014 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Early Devonian; HRCT scanning; Morphology; Petalichthyida; Placodermi
Index Keywords: Devonian; endemic species; extinction; fish; morphology; new genus; new species; paleogeography; phylogenetics; reconstruction; skull; three-dimensional modeling; tomography; China; Qujing; Yunnan; Placodermi

Authors: Rabal-Garcés R., Sauqué V.
Title: A new Pleistocene cave bear site in the high mountains of the Spanish Pyrenees: La Brecha del Rincón (Huesca, Spain)
Affiliations: Grupo Aragosaurus-IUCA, Dpto. Ciencias de la Tierra, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Zaragoza, Calle Pedro Cerbuna 12, Zaragoza, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Rabal-Garcés, R., Grupo Aragosaurus-IUCA, Dpto. Ciencias de la Tierra, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Zaragoza, Calle Pedro Cerbuna 12, Zaragoza, Spain; Sauqué, V., Grupo Aragosaurus-IUCA, Dpto. Ciencias de la Tierra, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Zaragoza, Calle Pedro Cerbuna 12, Zaragoza, Spain
Abstract: In the Pleistocene fossil record, bear remains are common, especially in karstic sites due to their hibernation behaviour. However, these fossils are rare in the Spanish Pyrenees, and even more in a high mountain environment. Now, a new karstic site called La Brecha del Rincón has recently been discovered in the Spanish Pyrenees at an altitude of 2160 m. In a preliminary fieldwork, 105 bear fossil remains have been recovered, mostly corresponding to autopodial bones. Dental remains with taxonomic value are not available, so metapodial bones have been used for our taxonomic study. These bones are short and thick, typical of cave bears, and their morphometric analysis supports their assignment to a species of Ursus deningeri group. This makes La Brecha del Rincón the highest cave bear site in the Iberian Peninsula.
Author Keywords: Metapodials; Pleistocene; Principal component analysis (PCA); Ursus deningeri group; Ursus spelaeus
Index Keywords: bear; bone; cave; fossil record; hibernation; karst; morphometry; mountain environment; paleobiogeography; Pleistocene; principal component analysis; taxonomy; tooth; Aragon; Huesca [Aragon]; Iberian Peninsula; Pyrenees; Spain; Ursus; Ursus spelaeus

Authors: Pereda-Suberbiola X., Pérez-García A., Corral J.C., Murelaga X., Martin G., Larrañaga J., Bardet N., Berreteaga A., Company J.
Title: First dinosaur and turtle remains from the latest Cretaceous shallow marine deposits of Albaina (Laño quarry, Iberian Peninsula)
Affiliations: Universidad del País Vasco/Euskal Herriko Unibertsitatea (UPV/EHU), Facultad de Ciencia y Tecnología, Departamento de Estratigrafía y Paleontología, Apartado 644, Bilbao, Spain; Centro de Geologia, Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa (FCUL), Edificio C6, Campo Grande, Lisboa, Portugal; Grupo de Biología Evolutiva, Facultad de Ciencias, UNED, Paseo de la Senda del Rey 9, Madrid, Spain; Museo de Ciencias Naturales de Álava/Arabako Natur Zientzien Museoa, Siervas de Jesús 24, Vitoria-Gasteiz, Spain; Luberri, Oiartzungo Ikasgune Geologikoa Museoa, Pagoaldea pol. 41-42, Oiartzun, Spain; Sorbonne Universités, CR2P CNRS-MNHN-UPMC Paris 6, Département Histoire de la Terre, Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle, CP 38, 57, rue Cuvier, Paris, France; Departamento de Ingeniería del Terreno, Universidad Politécnica de Valencia, Camino de Vera s/n, Valencia, Spain

Abstract: We report here on new vertebrate fossils from the latest Cretaceous of Albaina (Laño quarry, Condado de Treviño), northern Iberian Peninsula. They consist of an incomplete hadrosauroid femur and two partial plates of turtles, one belonging to a Pleurodira (Bothremydidae), the other one to an indeterminate taxon, probably corresponding to a Pan-Cryptodira. They are the first dinosaur and turtle remains found in the Late Maastrichtian sublittoral beds of Albaina. Other components of this shallow marine vertebrate fauna are selachians (sharks, rays), actinopterygians (pycnodonts, teleosts) and marine reptiles (mosasaurids, plesiosaurs). The Albaina femur is one of the few hadrosauroid remains from the Late Maastrichtian of Europe found in marine environments, and the first one described from this kind of deposits in the Iberian Peninsula. The histological structure of the bone indicates that it belongs to an immature individual of small size. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Bothremydidae; Condado de Treviño; Hadrosauroidea; Late Maastrichtian; Pan-Cryptodira; Spain

Authors: Peris D., Maier C.A., Sánchez-García A., Delclòs X.
Title: The oldest known riffle beetle (Coleoptera: Elmidae) from Early Cretaceous Spanish amber
Affiliations: Departament d'Estratigrafia, Paleontologia i Geociències Marines, Institut de Recerca de la Biodiversitat (IRBio), Facultat de Geologia, Universitat de Barcelona, Martí i Franquès s/n, Barcelona, Spain; Division of Entomology, Biodiversity Institute and Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peris, D., Departament d'Estratigrafia, Paleontologia i Geociències Marines, Institut de Recerca de la Biodiversitat (IRBio), Facultat de Geologia, Universitat de Barcelona, Martí i Franquès s/n, Barcelona, Spain; Maier, C.A., Division of Entomology, Biodiversity Institute and Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Sánchez-García, A., Departament d'Estratigrafia, Paleontologia i Geociències Marines, Institut de Recerca de la Biodiversitat (IRBio), Facultat de Geologia, Universitat de Barcelona, Martí i Franquès s/n, Barcelona, Spain; Delclòs, X., Departament d'Estratigrafia, Paleontologia i Geociències Marines, Institut de Recerca de la Biodiversitat (IRBio), Facultat de Geologia, Universitat de Barcelona, Martí i Franquès s/n, Barcelona, Spain
Abstract: Elmadulescens rugosus Peris, Maier et Sánchez-García n. gen. n. sp. is described based on a single specimen from Spanish amber (El Soplao outcrop, Early Albian, Early Cretaceous). The discovery of this specimen in amber is very interesting, since aquatic beetles are not common in fossil tree resin. This fossil pushes back the oldest known specimen of Elmidae from the Eocene (~ 40 Ma) to at least the Early Cretaceous (~ 110 Ma).
Author Keywords: Albian; Aquatic beetle; El Soplao; Fossil; Polyphaga; Spain
Index Keywords: Albian; amber; aquatic organism; beetle; Eocene; fossil record; Cantabria; Soplao Cave; Spain; Coleoptera; Elmidae; Polyphaga (Coleoptera)

Authors: Konidaris G.E., Tourloukis V., Kostopoulos D.S., Thompson N., Giusti D., Michailidis D., Koufos G.D., Harvati K.
Title: Two new vertebrate localities from the Early Pleistocene of Mygdonia Basin (Macedonia, Greece): Preliminary results
Affiliations: Eberhard Karls University of Tübingen, Palaeoanthropology, Senckenberg Center for Human Evolution and Palaeoenvironment, Rümelinstr. 23, Tübingen, Germany; Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Geology, Laboratory of Geology and Palaeontology, Thessaloniki, Greece; Friedrich-Alexander University of Erlangen-Nürnberg, Institute of Prehistory and Early History, Kochstr. 4/18, Erlangen, Germany; National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Faculty of Geology and Geoenvironment, Department of Historical Geology and Palaeontology, Panepistimiopolis, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Konidaris, G.E., Eberhard Karls University of Tübingen, Palaeoanthropology, Senckenberg Center for Human Evolution and Palaeoenvironment, Rümelinstr. 23, Tübingen, Germany; Tourloukis, V., Eberhard Karls University of Tübingen, Palaeoanthropology, Senckenberg Center for Human Evolution and Palaeoenvironment, Rümelinstr. 23, Tübingen, Germany; Kostopoulos, D.S., Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Geology, Laboratory of Geology and Palaeontology, Thessaloniki, Greece; Thompson, N., Friedrich-Alexander University of Erlangen-Nürnberg, Institute of Prehistory and Early History, Kochstr. 4/18, Erlangen, Germany; Giusti, D., Eberhard Karls University of Tübingen, Palaeoanthropology, Senckenberg Center for Human Evolution and Palaeoenvironment, Rümelinstr. 23, Tübingen, Germany; Michailidis, D., National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Faculty of Geology and Geoenvironment, Department of Historical Geology and Palaeontology, Panepistimiopolis, Athens, Greece; Koufos, G.D., Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Geology, Laboratory of Geology and Palaeontology, Thessaloniki, Greece; Harvati, K., Eberhard Karls University of Tübingen, Palaeoanthropology, Senckenberg Center for Human Evolution and Palaeoenvironment, Rümelinstr. 23, Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: Two new vertebrate fossiliferous localities from the Pleistocene of the Mygdonia Basin (Macedonia, Greece), Tsiotra Vryssi (TSR) and Platanochori-1 (PLN), are presented in this article. TSR belongs to the Gerakarou Formation and its preliminary faunal list includes the corvid Corvus pliocaenus, the hyaenid Pachycrocuta brevirostris, the canid Canis etruscus, the rhinoceros Stephanorhinus sp., two species of Equus, the bovid Bison sp., the cervid Metacervocerus rhenanus and the giraffid Palaeotragus sp. PLN belongs to the Platanochori Formation (overlying Gerakarou Formation) and its fauna includes the following taxa: Stephanorhinus hundsheimensis, Equus apolloniensis, Bison sp. and Pontoceros ambiguus. The preliminary comparison of these faunal assemblages with the already known localities from the Mygdonia Basin and the wider region, combined with the geological data, suggest a Late Villafranchian age for TSR, chronologically intermediate between the localities Gerakarou-1 and Apollonia-1, while the fauna from PLN is indicative of a Latest Villafranchian age, similar to that of Apollonia-1. These new localities will enhance our understanding of the crucial time period of the earliest dispersal of hominins into Europe. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Age; Fauna; Mammals; Platanochori-1; Tsiotra Vryssi; Villafranchian
Index Keywords: age; chronology; dispersal; fauna; fossil assemblage; hominid; type locality; vertebrate; Villafranchian; Greece; Macedonia [Greece]; Apollonia; Bison; Bovidae; Canidae; Canis; Cervidae; Corvida; Corvus; Equus; Giraffidae; Hyaenidae; Mammalia; Pachycrocuta brevirostris; Rhinoceros; Vertebrata

We are grateful to A. Darlas of the Ephoreia of Palaeoanthropology and Speleology (Northern Greece) for his support, as well as to the field team members for their contribution during the fieldwork. We thank B. Martínez-Navarro and two anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments.

Title: Fossil and subfossil herpetofauna from Cadet 2 Cave (Marie-Galante, Guadeloupe Islands, F. W. I.): Evolution of an insular herpetofauna since the Late Pleistocene

Authors with affiliations: Bochaton, C., Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle (MNHN), UMR 7209, Archéozoologie et archéobotanique: sociétes Pratiques et environnements (CNRS), CP 56, 55, rue Buffon, Paris, France, Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle (MNHN), ISYEB (UMR 7205 CNRS, EPHE, UPMC), CP 30, 57, rue Cuvier, Paris, France; Grouard, S., Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle (MNHN), UMR 7209, Archéozoologie et archéobotanique: sociétes Pratiques et environnements (CNRS), CP 56, 55, rue Buffon, Paris, France; Cornette, R., Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle (MNHN), ISYEB (UMR 7205 CNRS, EPHE, UPMC), CP 30, 57, rue Cuvier, Paris, France; Ineich, I., Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle (MNHN), ISYEB (UMR 7205 CNRS, EPHE, UPMC), CP 30, 57, rue Cuvier, Paris, France; Lenoble, A., Université de Bordeaux, UMR 5199 PACEA, Avenue des Facultés, Talence, France; Tresset, A., Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle (MNHN), UMR 7209, Archéozoologie et archéobotanique: sociétes Pratiques et environnements (CNRS), CP 56, 55, rue Buffon, Paris, France; Bailon, S., Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle (MNHN), UMR 7209, Archéozoologie et archéobotanique: sociétes Pratiques et environnements (CNRS), CP 56, 55, rue Buffon, Paris, France
Abstract: This study deals with the herpetofaunal fossil and subfossil remains from the Cadet 2 site (Marie-Galante, Guadeloupean Archipelago). This study provides new data concerning the herpetofaunal community since the Late Pleistocene by revealing the early local occurrence of some taxa (. Eleutherodactylus sp., cf. Sphaerodactylus sp., Ameiva sp., cf. Capitellum mariagalantae, Anolis cf. ferreus, cf. Antillotyphlops sp., cf. Alsophis sp. and Colubroidea sp. 1) and possible Pleistocene extinctions (. Boa sp. and Colubroidea sp. 2). Moreover, the first metric data for fossil Marie-Galante anoles show clear size stability throughout time. As regards the evolution of the island herpetofaunal biodiversity, our work points to the long-term stability of the fauna before human colonization and subsequently to the marked impact of human-caused environmental disturbances during colonial but also Pre-Columbian periods. © 2014 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Biodiversity; Extinction; Faunal turnover; Guadeloupe islands; Herpetofauna; Paleontology; West Indies
Index Keywords: biodiversity; cave; evolution; extinction; fossil record; herpetofauna; Pleistocene; species occurrence; Guadeloupe; Leeward Islands [Lesser Antilles]; Marie Galante; Alsophis; Ameiva; Anolis; Anolis ferreus; Colubroidea; Sphaerodactylus

Authors: Fernández M.S., Talevi M.
Title: An halisaurine (Squamata: Mosasauridae) from the Late Cretaceous of Patagonia, with a preserved tympanic disc: Insights into the mosasaur middle ear
Affiliations: CONICET - División Paleontología Vertebrados, Museo de La Plata, Paseo del Bosque s/n, La Plata, Argentina; CONICET - Instituto de Investigación en Paleobiología y Geología, Universidad Nacional de Río Negro, Isidro Lobo y Belgrano, General Roca, Río Negro, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Fernández, M.S., CONICET - División Paleontología Vertebrados, Museo de La Plata, Paseo del Bosque s/n, La Plata, Argentina; Talevi, M., CONICET - Instituto de Investigación en Paleobiología y Geología, Universidad Nacional de Río Negro, Isidro Lobo y Belgrano, General Roca, Río Negro, Argentina
Abstract: Halisaurinae is a subfamily of enigmatic, small- to medium-sized mosasauroids, which retain a mosaic of primitive and derived features. The first record of a South American Halisaurus with precise stratigraphic information includes a quadrate carrying a tympanic disc together with twelve vertebrae, collected in the Late Maastrichtian of Jagüel Formation in northern Patagonia (Argentina). The preservation of a tympanic disc allows exploring and discussing the mechanisms of sound transmission in these mosasauroids. The location of the tympanic disc resembles that one formed by the extracolumella of aquatic turtles and at least one extant lizard. Based on morphological comparison of the middle ear we discuss previous hypotheses on the modification of the tympanic middle ear system of mosasauroids for underwater hearing, in a manner similar to that observed in aquatic turtles. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Cretaceous; Halisaurus; Late Maastrichtian; Mosasauroidea; Patagonia; Tympanic disc
Index Keywords: anatomy; biostratigraphy; Cretaceous; hypothesis testing; morphology; reptile; sound propagation; Patagonia; Halisaurus; Mosasauridae; Mosasauroidea; Squamata; Testudines

Authors: Gaudant J., Garcia-Alix A., Freudenthal M.
Title: Occurrence of pharyngeal teeth of the carp, Cyprinus Linnaeus (Teleostei, Cyprinidae) in the Middle and Upper Miocene of Andalusia (southern Spain): A puzzling disconnected palaeobiogeographical distribution
Affiliations: USM 203 du Museum national d'histoire naturelle et UMR 7207 du CNRS, 17, rue du Docteur-Magnan, Paris, France; Instituto Andaluz de Ciencias de la Tierra (IACTCSIC-UGR), Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cientificas, Universidad de Granada, Avenida de las Palmeras n4, Armilla, Granada, Spain; Departamento de Estratigrafia y Paleontologia, Campus Fuentenueva, Universidad de Granada, Granada, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Gaudant, J., USM 203 du Museum national d'histoire naturelle et UMR 7207 du CNRS, 17, rue du Docteur-Magnan, Paris, France; Garcia-Alix, A., Instituto Andaluz de Ciencias de la Tierra (IACTCSIC-UGR), Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cientificas, Universidad de Granada, Avenida de las Palmeras n4, Armilla, Granada, Spain; Freudenthal, M., Departamento de Estratigrafia y Paleontologia, Campus Fuentenueva, Universidad de Granada, Granada, Spain
Abstract: Three pharyngeal teeth of carp, Cyprinus Linnaeus, were found when washing and screening sediment in the Middle and Upper Miocene of Andalusia (Spain). Their examination has shown that they look very similar to those of the recent carp, Cyprinus carpio Linnaeus, so that it would not be impossible that they belong to this species. Their presence in southern Spain at that time is surprising because Cyprinus remains are unknown before the Pleistocene in the countries westward of Ukraine, as no articulated skeleton or bony fragment of this genus has ever been identified in the many Mio-Pliocene localities investigated throughout central and western Europe. © 2014 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Cyprinidae; Cyprinus; Middle Miocene; Palaeobiogeography; South Spain; Teleost; Upper Miocene

Authors: Liu X., Béthoux O., Yin X., Ren D.
Title: The smallest Palaeodictyoptera (Insecta) discovered at Xiaheyan (Late Carboniferous, China)
Affiliations: Key Laboratory of Insect Evolution and Environmental Changes, College of Life Science, Capital Normal University, Beijing, China; Centre de recherches sur la paleobiodiversite et les paléoenvironnements (CR2P, UMR 7207), Sorbonne universités - MNHN, CNRS, UPMC (Université Paris-6), Muséum national d'histoire naturelle, 57, rue Cuvier, CP38, Paris, France; Northwest Institute of Plateau Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 23, Xinning Road, Xining, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, X., Key Laboratory of Insect Evolution and Environmental Changes, College of Life Science, Capital Normal University, Beijing, China; Béthoux, O., Centre de recherches sur la paleobiodiversite et les paléoenvironnements (CR2P, UMR 7207), Sorbonne universités - MNHN, CNRS, UPMC (Université Paris-6), Muséum national d'histoire naturelle, 57, rue Cuvier, CP38, Paris, France; Yin, X., Northwest Institute of Plateau Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 23, Xinning Road, Xining, China; Ren, D., Key Laboratory of Insect Evolution and Environmental Changes, College of Life Science, Capital Normal University, Beijing, China
Abstract: Fossil insects of the Late Carboniferous have been popularized as lost giants of the past. However, their small contemporaries are very poorly known. In this paper, we report the discovery of the smallest known member of the Palaeodictyoptera, an extinct group of sap-feeders including some of the largest insects ever known. The new representative, Tytthospilaptera wangae, collected at the Xiaheyan locality (Ningxia, China; early Late Carboniferous), belongs to the Spilapteridae and had a wing span of only about 2. cm. Observed veins elevation is best explained by a simple (convex) MA with a (concave) branch of MP translocated onto it. This pattern is congruent with the one involving a series of 'simple anterior sectors and branched posterior sectors', observed in many Palaeodictyoptera families. We compiled size data on the corresponding superfamily (viz., the Spilapteroidea). The available sample is found insufficient to adequately test the hypothesis of a global effect of an elevated atmospheric pO2 on the size of these insects during the late Late Carboniferous vs. that of a lineage-specific trend possibly driven by an arms race in size. More intensive sampling appears necessary to address such evolutionary questions. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Namurian; Size distribution; Spilapteridae
Index Keywords: arms race; Carboniferous; evolutionary theory; fossil assemblage; hypothesis testing; insect; size distribution; wing morphology; Hexapoda; Insecta; Palaeodictyoptera

Authors: Rage J.-C.
Title: France de Lapparent de Broin: Specialist of turtles and crocodiles
Affiliations: Sorbonne Universités, CR2P, CNRS, UPMC-Paris 6, Muséum national d'histoire naturelle (MNHN), CP 38, 57, rue Cuvier, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Rage, J.-C., Sorbonne Universités, CR2P, CNRS, UPMC-Paris 6, Muséum national d'histoire naturelle (MNHN), CP 38, 57, rue Cuvier, Paris, France
Abstract: France de Lapparent de Broin is an expert on extinct crocodiles and turtles who has made them known to the paleoherpetological community over almost 50. years. Her studies have dealt with fossils from the Mesozoic (mostly the Cretaceous) and the Cenozoic (mainly the Eocene and Miocene). She has been interested in faunas originating mainly from Europe, Africa and South America, and she produced large reviews of turtles from these continents. She erected several taxa, mostly of turtles. Among these taxa are some strange forms that appear to represent unique morphological types. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Cenozoic; Chelonians; Crocodilians; Mesozoic; Paleontology; Vertebrates
Index Keywords: Cenozoic; crocodilian; fossil record; herpetofauna; Mesozoic; morphology; paleobiology; specialist; turtle; Africa; Europe; South America; Crocodylidae (all crocodiles); Testudines; Vertebrata

Authors: Taquet P.
Title: From the Aoulef crocodile to Sarcosuchus imperator [Du crocodile d'Aoulef au Sarcosuchus imperator]
Affiliations: Muséum national d'histoire naturelle, Département Histoire de la Terre, CP 38, UMR 7207, Centre de recherche sur la paléobiodiversité et les paléoenvironnements, 8, rue Buffon, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Taquet, P., Muséum national d'histoire naturelle, Département Histoire de la Terre, CP 38, UMR 7207, Centre de recherche sur la paléobiodiversité et les paléoenvironnements, 8, rue Buffon, Paris, France
Abstract: This paper is a tribute to my colleague and friend France de Lapparent; it recounts briefly all the stages of a nice paleontological discovery, which began in Algeria in 1947, when the geologist Albert-Felix de Lapparent collected fragments of a crocodile of massive size in Lower Cretaceous sediments. The study of these fragments by France de Lapparent, and the subsequent discovery in Niger of a skull and elements of the skeleton of a crocodile of the same species by the author of these lines, led us together to describe and to name this monster Sarcosuchus imperator, which is today famous under the nickname Supercroc. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Africa; Cretaceous; Crocodile; Mesozoic
Index Keywords: biostratigraphy; Cretaceous; crocodilian; Mesozoic; paleontology; skull; Algeria

Authors: Vijande Vila E., Domínguez-Bella S., Cantillo Duarte J.J., Martínez López J., Barrena Tocino A.
Title: Social inequalities in the Neolithic of southern Europe: The grave goods of the Campo de Hockey necropolis (San Fernando, Cádiz, Spain)
Affiliations: Prehistory Area, Cádiz University, Faculty of Letters, Cádiz, Spain; Earth Sciences Department, UGEA-PHAM. Cádiz University, Puerto Real, Cádiz, Spain; Cádiz University, Faculty of Letters, Cádiz, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Vijande Vila, E., Prehistory Area, Cádiz University, Faculty of Letters, Cádiz, Spain; Domínguez-Bella, S., Earth Sciences Department, UGEA-PHAM. Cádiz University, Puerto Real, Cádiz, Spain; Cantillo Duarte, J.J., Cádiz University, Faculty of Letters, Cádiz, Spain; Martínez López, J., Earth Sciences Department, UGEA-PHAM. Cádiz University, Puerto Real, Cádiz, Spain; Barrena Tocino, A., Prehistory Area, Cádiz University, Faculty of Letters, Cádiz, Spain
Abstract: The archaeological excavations carried out between August 2007 and July 2008 in the necropolis of Campo de Hockey (transit Vth-IVth millennium BC) documented levels and structures of interest. We report the first data on the grave goods study, with a special focus on the "funerary" as social work investment. The correlations between the "grave goods" (such as social prestige values) and funerary structures can be established. The individual, double or triple characters of these burials imply social effort and sometimes involve an investment of community work. In the study of the necropolis, it has been observed that very few tombs have grave goods elements; this finding is of great interest because it confirms that incipient hierarchisation processes occurred in these Neolithic societies of South Iberia. We emphasise the analysis of so-called exotic products (amber, turquoise, variscite, sillimanite, etc.) as indicators of inequality, focusing on the correspondence between them and the most monumental or complex structures. We also note the importance of the exploitation of marine resources, which is obvious given the insular nature of the settlement, not only for food but also for ornamental purposes. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Amber; Exotic products; Necropolis; Neolithic; Social hierarchical organisation; Southwest Europe; Variscite-turquoise
Index Keywords: archaeological evidence; cemetery; correlation; exploitation; gemstone; local participation; marine resource; Neolithic; new record; spatiotemporal analysis; Andalucia; Cadiz [Andalucia]; Iberian Peninsula; Spain
Funding Text: This study was partially supported by the I + D + I Spanish national research DGI project HAR2008-06477-C03-02/HIST, ‘La implantación de las especies domésticas en la Europa Atlántica: Sociedades Neolíticas y uso de materias primas líticas en la región del Estrecho de Gibraltar’, by the research group P.A.I. HUM-440 of the Junta de Andalucia government. Variscite and turquoise analysis was performed under the CALLAIS project, directed by S. Domínguez-Bella, with transnational access to the AGLAE facility of the C2RMF, Paris, France, provided in 2010 under the CHARISMA Cultural Heritage Advanced Research Infrastructures, 7th European Framework Program. Authorisation for the excavations was provided by the Andalusian government. Laboratory work was performed in the UGEA-PHAM Archaeometrical Unit of the University of Cádiz and in the Municipal Museum of San Fernando, Cádiz. The authors are grateful to the two anonymous reviewers and editors for providing very helpful comments and suggestions. Finally, we thank Ms. Ana Durante for her editorial assistance and Max Luaces for the French translation.

Authors: Romandini M., Cristiani E., Peresani M.
Title: A retouched bone shaft from the Late Mousterian at Fumane cave (Italy). Technological, experimental and micro-wear analysis
Affiliations: Universita di Ferrara, Dipartimento di Studi Umanistici, Sezione di Preistoria e Antropologia, Corso Ercole I d'Este. 32, Ferrara, Italy; McDonald Institute for Archaeological Research, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Romandini, M., Universita di Ferrara, Dipartimento di Studi Umanistici, Sezione di Preistoria e Antropologia, Corso Ercole I d'Este. 32, Ferrara, Italy; Cristiani, E., McDonald Institute for Archaeological Research, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Peresani, M., Universita di Ferrara, Dipartimento di Studi Umanistici, Sezione di Preistoria e Antropologia, Corso Ercole I d'Este. 32, Ferrara, Italy
Abstract: This paper describes a retouched bone shaft found in a Late Mousterian layer at Fumane Cave, northern Italy. The interpretation of the anthropic nature of the retouch is based on the identification of specific morpho-technological markers through experimentation. An integrated taphonomic and technological analysis was applied to the archaeological artifact. The evidence suggests that the bone shaft modifications involved the use of direct percussion through a transfer of technical knowledge from flint knapping. However, this does not necessarily imply that this technique was used in the absence of a more effective one. Similar cases of the use of bone as raw material for tool manufacturing are documented in the Lower Palaeolithic, and might have been related to the lack of appropriate lithic raw material, although this is not the case for Fumane cave. © 2014 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Bone tool; Mousterian; Retouch; Taphonomy; Zooarchaeology
Index Keywords: archaeology; bone; morphology; Mousterian; taphonomy; technological change; Fumane Cave; Italy; Veneto; Verona

Authors: de la Fuente M.S., Maniel I.J., Jannello J.M., Filippi L.S., Cerda I.
Title: Long-necked chelid turtles from the Campanian of northwestern Patagonia with comments on K/P survivorship of the genus Yaminuechelys
Affiliations: CONICET, Argentina; IANIGLA-Museo de Historia Natural de San Rafael. Parque Mariano Moreno, Av, Balloffet s/n (5600), San Rafael, Mendoza, Argentina; Museo Municipal Argentino Urquiza, Jujuy y Chaco s/n (8319), Rincon de los Sauces, Neuquén, Argentina; Instituto de Investigación en Paleobiología y Geología, Universidad Nacional de Rio Negro, Museo Carlos Ameghino, Belgrano 1700, Paraje Pichi Ruca (predio Marabunta), Cipolletti, Argentina

Parque Mariano Moreno, Av, Balloffet s/n (5600), San Rafael, Mendoza, Argentina; Maniel, I.J., CONICET, Argentina, IANIGLA-Museo de Historia Natural de San Rafael. Parque Mariano Moreno, Av, Balloffet s/n (5600), San Rafael, Mendoza, Argentina; Jannello, J.M., CONICET, Argentina, IANIGLA-Museo de Historia Natural de San Rafael. Parque Mariano Moreno, Av, Balloffet s/n (5600), San Rafael, Mendoza, Argentina; Filippi, L.S., Museo Municipal Argentino Urquiza, Jujuy y Chaco s/n (8319), Rincon de los Sauces, Neuquén, Argentina; Cerda, I., CONICET, Argentina, Instituto de Investigación en Paleobiología y Geología, Universidad Nacional de Rio Negro, Museo Carlos Ameghino, Belgrano 1700, Paraje Pichi Ruca (predio Marabunta), Cipolletti, Argentina
Abstract: The long-necked chelid turtle Yaminuechelys aff. maior is described on the basis of post-cranial material of two specimens from the Lower-Middle Campanian Anacleto Formation, nortwestern Patagonia (Argentina). These post-cranial remains are described macroscopically (external morphology) and microscopically (histological sections of the shell). Although minor carapace and plastral differences are reported (e.g., extension of the axillary buttresses on visceral surfaces of the first costal bone, curled bridge peripheral bones, absence of a sub-rectangular fenestra retained in adults) the specimens exibit the shell morphology and surface ornamentation of specimens referred to Y. maior (Staesche, 1929) from Paleocene levels of the Salamanca Formation (Central Patagonia). This assignment is supported by a phylogenetic analysis, in which the new material is the most closely related to Y. maior. As Yaminuechelys is hypothesized to be the sister taxon of Hydromedusa, the capability of Hydromedusa tectifera to adapt to changing environments and the survivorship of Yaminuechelys genus in K/P boundary is discussed. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Chelidae; Patagonia; Pleurodira; South America; Upper cretaceous
Index Keywords: bone; Cretaceous-Tertiary boundary; histology; morphology; Paleocene; phylogenetics; shell; survivorship; turtle; Patagonia; Chelidae; Hydromedusa; Hydromedusa tectifera; Pleurodira; Testudines

The illustration of the turtle material was made by Salvador Palomo (Rincón de los Sauces) and Jorge Gonzalez (La Plata). Mariano Caffa (MEF) made the histological sections. Cecilia Deschamps (La Plata) helped with the grammar revision. We are much indebted to three anonymous reviewers and the editor (Nathalie Bardet) for useful suggestions and comments that improved the quality of the manuscript. Authors: Fortuny J., Steyer J.-S., Hosgör I.
Title: First occurrence of temnospondyls from the Permian and Triassic of Turkey: Paleoenvironmental and paleobiogeographic implications
Affiliations: Institut Català de Paleontologia Miquel Crusafont, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, Edifici ICTA-ICP, Carrer de les Columnes s/n, Campus de la UAB, Cerdanyola del Vallés, Barcelona, Spain; CR2P, UMR 7207 CNRS-MNHN-UPMC, Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, 8, rue Buffon, CP38, 75005, Paris, France; Çalik Energy, Ak Plaza, Yasam Caddesi no7-Kat 9, Sögütözü-Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Fortuny, J., Institut Català de Paleontologia Miquel Crusafont, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, Edifici ICTA-ICP, Carrer de les Columnes s/n, Campus de la UAB, Cerdanyola del Vallés, Barcelona, Spain; Steyer, J.-S., CR2P, UMR 7207 CNRS-MNHN-UPMC, Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, 8, rue Buffon, CP38, 75005, Paris, France; Hosgör, I., Çalik Energy, Ak Plaza, Yasam Caddesi no7-Kat 9, Sögütözü-Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: Permian and Triassic tetrapods are very rare in Turkey. Yet this group bears important paleoenvironmental and paleogeographical signals to better understand Pangean models, and especially the geodynamic history of the Permian and Triassic in Turkey, which remains highly debated. Here we present and describe the first temnospondyls from Turkey (SE Anatolia) which consist of a Middle Permian branchiosaurid and an Early Triassic stereospondyl. The branchiosaurid is the first representative of its group in Gondwana and the first from the Middle Permian: it therefore brings important paleogeographic implications and supports the hypothesis that anamniotic tetrapods may have used trans-Pangean migration routes between Europe and Gondwana. It also brings new data to the debated depositional environment of the Permian of SE Anatolia. The Triassic stereospondyl represents one of the few tetrapods known from paleoequatorial areas and confirms a relatively rapid faunal turnover of the anamniotic fauna after the Permian-Triassic mass extinction.
Author Keywords: Anatolia; Branchiosauridae; Early Triassic; Middle Permian; Pangean migrations; Stereospondyli
Index Keywords: amphibian; depositional environment; Gondwana; historical ecology; mass extinction; migration; paleobiogeography; paleoenvironment; Pangaea; Permian; Triassic; Anatolia; Europe; Turkey; Branchiosauridae; Stereospondyli; Tetrapoda
Funding Details: FR-TAF-3353; ENERGY, FP7 Energy

Authors: Brinkman D.B., Tong H.-Y., Li H., Sun Y., Zhang J.-S., Godefroit P., Zhang Z.-M.
Title: New exceptionally well-preserved specimens of "Zangerlia" neimongolensis from Bayan Mandahu, Inner Mongolia, and their taxonomic significance
Affiliations: Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology, Adjunct researcher, Department of Biological Sciences, University of Alberta, Box 7500, Drumheller, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Palaeontological Research and Education Centre, Mahasarakham University, Kantarawichai, Mahasarakham, Thailand; Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, 142 Xizhimenwai St., Beijing, China; Inner Mongolia Museum, No. 27 Eastern Xinhua Street, Hohhote, Inner Mongolia, China; Royal Belgium Institute of Natural Sciences, rue Vautier 29, Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Brinkman, D.B., Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology, Adjunct researcher, Department of Biological Sciences, University of Alberta, Box 7500, Drumheller, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Tong, H.-Y., Palaeontological Research and Education Centre, Mahasarakham University, Kantarawichai, Mahasarakham, Thailand, Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, 142 Xizhimenwai St., Beijing, China; Li, H., Inner Mongolia Museum, No. 27 Eastern Xinhua Street, Hohhote, Inner Mongolia, China; Sun, Y., Inner Mongolia Museum, No. 27 Eastern Xinhua Street, Hohhote, Inner Mongolia, China; Zhang, J.-S., Inner Mongolia Museum, No. 27 Eastern Xinhua Street, Hohhote, Inner Mongolia, China; Godefroit, P., Royal Belgium Institute of Natural Sciences, rue Vautier 29, Brussels, Belgium; Zhang, Z.-M., Inner Mongolia Museum, No. 27 Eastern Xinhua Street, Hohhote, Inner Mongolia, China
Abstract: Two exceptionally well-preserved specimens of "Zangerlia" neimongolensis provide additional information on the structure of the skull, shell and limbs of this taxon. These specimens show that the carapace is more similar to that of Hanbogdemys than was previously recognized. A PAUP analysis results in a single most parsimonious cladogram in which the type species of Zangerlia, Zangerlia testudinimorpha is separated from other species that have been included in that genus while " Z." neimongolensis, " Zangerlia" ukaachelys and " Zangerlia" dzamynchondi and Jiangxichelys are grouped together. Both specimens are exceptional in being preserved in a life-like position: one is preserved with the skull in a retracted position; the other with the head and left forelimb both protracted and in a raised position. These positions suggest that they were entombed while still alive. Thus these specimens provide additional examples of rapid burial of vertebrates in the Bayan Mandahu locality, most likely from either by sand storms that dumped massive amounts of sand over a short period of time or by collapse of individuals in burrows. © 2015.

Authors: Garcia J., Martínez K.
Title: Reviewing the chronology and palaeoenvironment of the early hominin occupation of Vallparadís EVT7 (Barcelona, Spain): Reply to Lozano-Fernández et al. (Quat. Int.)
Affiliations: IPHES, Institut Català de Paleoecologia Humana i Evolució Social (IPHES), C/Marcelli Domingo s/n, Campus Sescelades URV, Tarragona, Spain; URV, Universitat Rovira i Virgili, Area de Prehistoria, Avinguda de Catalunya 35, Tarragona, Spain; UOC, Universitat Oberta de Catalunya (UOC), Avinguda del Tibidabo 39-43, Barcelona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Garcia, J., IPHES, Institut Català de Paleoecologia Humana i Evolució Social (IPHES), C/Marcelli Domingo s/n, Campus Sescelades URV, Tarragona, Spain, URV, Universitat Rovira i Virgili, Area de Prehistoria, Avinguda de Catalunya 35, Tarragona, Spain, UOC, Universitat Oberta de Catalunya (UOC), Avinguda del Tibidabo 39-43, Barcelona, Spain; Martínez, K., IPHES, Institut Català de Paleoecologia Humana i Evolució Social (IPHES), C/Marcelli Domingo s/n, Campus Sescelades URV, Tarragona, Spain, URV, Universitat Rovira i Virgili, Area de Prehistoria, Avinguda de Catalunya 35, Tarragona, Spain
Abstract: The article by Lozano-Fernández et al. (2015) revises the chronological range and paleoenvironmental inferences for unit EVT7 at Vallparadís, based on a micromammal sample slightly larger than the original one published in Martínez et al. (2014). However, in this new chronological and paleoenvironmental interpretation, the virtually identical results (0.95-0.98 Myr and predominant humid landscape) for the site published in Martínez et al. (2014) are omitted. Furthermore, they claim an age of ca. 1.2 Myr for unit EVT7 at Vallparadís, attributing this chronology to the archaeological team who excavated the site. However, this proposal is not in accordance with the date close to the upper boundary of the Jaramillo subchron (ca. 0.9 Myr), which this team has defended in their articles. Thus, the results and conclusions presented by Lozano-Fernández et al. (2015) do not revise previous studies, but rather confirm the interpretations drawn from the sample analyzed by Martínez et al. (2014). © 2015 Académie des sciences.

Authors: Pérez-García A., Murelaga X., Mancheño M.T., Aberasturi Rodriguez A., Romero G.
Title: The tortoises from the Lower Pleistocene palaeontological site of Quibas (Región de Murcia, Spain)
Affiliations: Centro de Geologia, Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa (FCUL), Edificio C6, Campo Grande, Lisbon, Portugal; Grupo de Biología Evolutiva, Facultad de Ciencias, UNED, Senda del Rey, 9, Madrid, Spain; Departamento de Estratigrafía y Paleontología, Facultad de Ciencia y Tecnología, Universidad del País Vasco, Apartado 644, Bilbao, Spain; Departamento de Química Agrícola, Geología y Edafología, Universidad de Murcia, Murcia, Spain; Fundación Cidaris-Museo Paleontológico de Elche, Elche, Spain

Abstract: Turtle remains from the Lower Pleistocene palaeontological site of Quibas (Sierra de Quibas, Región de Murcia, Spain) are abundant, but they have not been analyzed taxonomically. Here we determine that all diagnostic specimens belong to Hermann's Tortoise (Chersine hermanni or Testudo hermanni) and they represent the oldest Iberian known occurrence of this taxon. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Hermann's Tortoise; Lower Pleistocene; Quibas; Testudinidae
Index Keywords: abundance; biostratigraphy; fossil record; identification key; paleontology; Pleistocene; species occurrence; taxonomy; turtle; Iberian Peninsula; Chersine; Testudines; Testudinidae; Testudo hermanni

Authors: Freund K.P., Tykot R.H., Vianello A.
Title: Blade production and the consumption of obsidian in Stentinello period Neolithic Sicily
Affiliations: Department of Social Sciences/Anthropology, Indian River State College, 3209, Virginia avenue, Fort Pierce, FL, United States; Department of anthropology, University of South Florida, 4202, East Fowler avenue, SOC107, Tampa, FL, United States; Institute, Learning Technologies Group, Oxford University, Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Freund, K.P., Department of Social Sciences/Anthropology, Indian River State College, 3209, Virginia avenue, Fort Pierce, FL, United States; Tykot, R.H., Department of anthropology, University of South Florida, 4202, East Fowler avenue, SOC107, Tampa, FL, United States; Vianello, A., Institute, Learning Technologies Group, Oxford University, Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: This study explores obsidian consumption during the Early/Middle Neolithic Stentinello period (ca. 5600-4000 cal B.C.) on the Italian island of Sicily through the analysis of 622 obsidian artifacts from eight sites in eastern Sicily and the Aeolian Islands. By combining obsidian sourcing by means of portable X-ray fluorescence (pXRF) spectrometry with techno-typological characterization, it is shown that distinctively wide Lipari blades were the primary artifact type used during this period. Our data suggest that the primary reduction of these materials occurred at the source area by local populations, with obsidian being transported from Lipari to eastern Sicily and Calabria in the form of preformed cores. Despite similarities between Sicily and southern Italy in the initial procurement of Lipari obsidian, there are distinct differences in how these materials were subsequently reduced.
Author Keywords: Exchange Networks; Lithic Technology; Neolithic; Obsidian Sourcing; Portable X-ray Fluorescence (pXRF); Sicily; West Mediterranean
Index Keywords: artifact; island; lithic fragment; Mediterranean environment; Neolithic; obsidian; physical analysis; reduction; X-ray fluorescence; Calabria; Italy; Lipari Islands; Messina [Sicily]; Sicily
Funding Text: We would like to thank the Director of the Paolo Orsi Regional Archaeological Museum, Dr. Beatrice Basile, for allowing us access to the analyzed material. We would also like to acknowledge Dr. Anita Crispino for her precious assistance and Dr. Giuseppina Monterosso for her support. In Lipari, the warm welcome provided by Dr. Maria Clara Martinelli was much appreciated. Comments on an early draft of this paper were provided by Tristan Carter and Albert Ammerman.

Title: Mosasauroid (Squamata) discovery in the Late Cretaceous (Early Campanian) continental deposits of Villeveyrac-L'Olivet, southern France

Abstract: New mosasauroid material from the Villeveyrac-L'Olivet mine (Hérault, southern France) is described. This historical and fossiliferous bauxite mine has yielded from the same stratigraphical level (Early Campanian) diverse continental vertebrates, including fishes (Lepisosteidae and Phyllodontidae), amphibians (Albanerpetondidae and the oldest representative of the Palaeobatrachidae), turtles (Solemydidae and Bothremydidae), squamates (Mosasauroidea), crocodilians (Eusuchia), dinosaurs (Rhabdodontidae, Nodosauridae and Dromaeosauridae), and a possible pterosaur. The mosasauroid specimens represent different individuals of a single taxon, belonging to a large plesiopedal tethysaurine-like form (about 3. meters long). This discovery adds to previous reports of plesiomorphic freshwater mosasauroids in the Late Cretaceous dinosaur-bearing sites of the European archipelago. © 2015 Académie des sciences.
Author Keywords: Early Campanian; Mosasauroidea; Non-marine vertebrates; Southern France; Villeveyrac-Mèze Basin
Index Keywords: amphibian; archipelago; bauxite; biostratigraphy; continental lithosphere; Cretaceous; dinosaur; fish; fossil record; mine; new record; pterosaur; taxonomy; turtle; type specimen; France; Herault; Languedoc-Roussillon; Mosasauroidea; Squamata; Vertebrata

Funding Text: We gratefully acknowledge for the management and the logistical assistance: R. Courtieu and D. Fourrier (general directors of the mine des Usclades), G. Sorli and J. Garcia and D. Escanez (Sodicapei society), the Villeveyrac Municipality, and the numerous field volunteers (GGN Narbonne). We also thank B. Gomez, L. Cavin, J. Sudre, M. Vianey-Liaud, M. Benammi, M. Feist, J. Galtier, B. Marandat, F. Escuillié, A. Cabot, E. Buffetaut and Y. Thellière (for the cast of the vertebra No. 1588). All the authors are very grateful to contribute to this volume in honor of France de Lapparent de Broin. For all of us, especially for the three female authors, she represents a pioneering, intrepid and courageous woman that opened the field of palaeoherpetology to women in France (but also in Europe and worldwide), at a time when this discipline was mainly reserved to men. N.B. and G.G. are particularly indebted to the enjoyable hours spent with her, not only the ones dedicated to professional activities, but also the private ones. N.B. is especially grateful for the formative and instructive data she provided her on Chelonioid comparative anatomy. G.G. is extremely grateful to her for having supported, guided and transferred her knowledge on the turtles, especially the African pleurodires. Research of X.P.-S. is supported by the Ministerio de Economía y Competitividad of Spain (project CGL2013-47521-P) and European Regional Development Fund, and by the Gobierno Vasco/Eusko Jaurlaritza (research group IT834-13). Finally, we thank A. Schulp (Leiden, The Netherlands) and R. Holmes (Edmonton, Alberta, Canada) for their constructive reviews that permitted to greatly improve our manuscript.
